abstracts.cdata!:
The Urban Sector and Regional
            Development Project was considered satisfactory in the
            achievement of its objectives and its outcome. The lessons
            learned include the following: 1) The appropriateness of a
            Project Implementation Unit outside of the civil service
            structure is based on considering the long-term development
            role of the project's implementation arrangements, and
            the need for inter-ministerial coordination and
            collaboration in implementing the project's development
            objectives. 2) The Public Sector Investment Program (PSIP)
            was the key source of counterpart funding under the project.
            A key lessons learned is that the mixing of fiscal and
            financial policies of central government in
            intergovernmental relations is not sustainable and not
            desirable in implementation of sound decentralization
            policy. 3) Local government projects needs to recognize the
            diversity of local capacity and to include mechanisms to
            improve this capacity. 4) The role of a central ministry
            responsible for local government policies should result in a
            policy shift from an emphasis on "command and
            control" to more devolution. 5) Networking and
            dissemination have proved to be very important and
            effective. 6) Fiscal and financial instruments for support
            to local government need to be carefully separated, with
            appropriate policy and implementation arrangements being
            formulated and implemented.
